entry.title: 词汇
entry.content:
monument

  • 简明

英/ˈmɒnjumənt/美/ˈmɑːnjumənt/
n.纪念碑，纪念馆，纪念物；遗址，名胜古迹；典范；塑像，墓碑；有永久价值的作品

v.为……树碑

高中 | CET4 | CET6 | 考研 | IELTS | TOEFL
复数monuments

  • 柯林斯

monument/ˈmɒnjʊmənt/|CET4 TEM4

  1. N-COUNT A monument is a large structure, usually made of stone, which is built to remind people of an event in history or of a famous person. 纪念碑

    • …a newly restored monument commemorating a 119-year-old tragedy.
    …为纪念一起有着119年历史的惨剧而新修复的一座纪念碑。

  2. N-COUNT A monument is something such as a castle or bridge that was built a very long time ago and is regarded as an important part of a country’s history. 历史遗迹

    • …the ancient monuments of Mexico and Peru.
    …墨西哥和秘鲁的历史古迹。

  3. N-COUNT If you describe something as a monument to someone’s qualities, you mean that it is a very good example of the results or effects of those qualities. 典范

    • By his international achievements he leaves a fitting monument to his beliefs.
    他在国际上的成就恰好成为他信仰的一个例证。

statue

  • 简明

英/ˈstætʃuː/美/ˈstætʃuː/
n.（石或金属做的动物或人的）雕像

高中 | CET4 | CET6 | 考研 | IELTS | TOEFL | SAT
复数statues

  • 柯林斯

statue/ˈstætjuː/|CET4 TEM4
N-COUNT A statue is a large sculpture of a person or an animal, made of stone or metal. (石或金属做的动物或人的) 雕像

• …a bronze statue of an Arabian horse.
…一座阿拉伯马青铜雕像。

sculpture

  • 简明

英/ˈskʌlptʃə(r)/美/ˈskʌlptʃər/
n.雕像，雕塑作品；雕刻艺术，雕塑艺术；（动，植）（贝壳、花粉粒、角质层或其他生物体表面凸起或凹陷的）雕饰，雕纹

v.雕刻，雕塑；从事雕刻

高中 | CET6 | 考研 | IELTS | TOEFL | GRE | GMAT
复数sculptures第三人称单数sculptures现在分词sculpturing过去式sculptured过去分词sculptured

  • 柯林斯

sculpture/ˈskʌlptʃə/|CET6 TEM4

  1. N-VAR A sculpture is a work of art that is produced by carving or shaping stone, wood, clay, or other materials. 雕塑

    • …stone sculptures of figures and animals.
    …人物及动物石雕。

  2. N-UNCOUNT Sculpture is the art of creating sculptures. 雕塑 (艺术)

    • Both studied sculpture.
    两人都学过雕塑。

moderation

  • Chatgpt

“Moderation” 是一个名词，意思是适度、节制或中庸。它指的是在行为、态度或反应中保持适中的状态，不过分也不不及，常常强调平衡和控制。

定义

Moderation：适度，节制，中庸。指在数量、强度或程度上保持适中的状态，不极端。

用法和例句

  1. 描述行为或态度

    • He eats sweets in moderation to maintain his health.
      • 他适量吃甜食以保持健康。

  2. 描述某种程度或量

    • Moderation in all things is the key to a balanced life.
      • 凡事适度是保持平衡生活的关键。

  3. 描述调节或控制

    • The moderator ensured that the debate was conducted in moderation.
      • 调解人确保辩论以适度进行。

相关词汇

  • Restraint：克制，指控制或抑制情绪、行为等。

    • She showed restraint by not reacting angrily.
    • 她表现出克制，没有愤怒地反应。

  • Balance：平衡，指均衡状态。

    • A balanced diet is important for good health.
    • 均衡的饮食对健康很重要。

  • Temperance：节制，通常指对饮食、酒精等的节制。

    • The movement promoted temperance as a way to improve society.
    • 这场运动提倡节制以改善社会。

语法

Moderation 是不可数名词，因此没有复数形式。

例句解析

  1. She believes in moderation when it comes to exercise, avoiding both excessive workouts and inactivity.

    • 她在锻炼方面相信适度，避免过度锻炼和不活动。
    • 这里的 “moderation” 表示在锻炼强度上保持适中。

  2. Drinking alcohol in moderation is generally considered safe.

    • 适量饮酒通常被认为是安全的。
    • 这里的 “in moderation” 表示适量饮酒。

  3. The principle of moderation can be applied to various aspects of life, from eating habits to spending.

    • 适度的原则可以应用于生活的各个方面，从饮食习惯到消费。
    • 这里的 “moderation” 指在多个方面保持适度。

背景信息

“Moderation” 是一个强调平衡和适度的概念，常常出现在健康、饮食、生活方式等方面的讨论中。适度意味着不过度地追求某一方面，而是在各方面保持一种平衡和控制。这种理念在许多文化和哲学中都被提倡，例如古希腊哲学中的“中庸之道”。

通过这些解释和例子，希望你对“moderation”这个单词有了更全面的理解。

日拱一卒

  • Chatgpt

“日拱一卒”是一种比喻，意思是每天努力做一点点，积累小进步，最终达到目标。它的英文表达可以是：

  1. “Progress one step at a time.”
  2. “Move forward one step at a time.”
  3. “Advance step by step each day.”
  4. “Make gradual progress every day.”

这些表达方式传达了每天不断努力，积累小进步的意思。可以根据具体语境选择最合适的表达方式。例如：

  • “Success comes from progressing one step at a time.”
  • “If you move forward one step at a time, you’ll eventually reach your goal.”
  • “Advance step by step each day to achieve your dreams.”
  • “By making gradual progress every day, you can accomplish great things.”

Eventually

  • Chatgpt

“Eventually” 是一个副词，用来表示某件事情最终会发生，尽管可能经过了一段时间或经历了一些过程。它相当于中文的“最终”，“终于”，或者“最后”。

用法和例句

  1. 表示经过时间后最终发生

    • He studied hard and eventually passed the exam.
      • 他努力学习，最终通过了考试。
    • They searched for hours and eventually found the missing keys.
      • 他们找了好几个小时，最后找到了丢失的钥匙。

  2. 强调结果或结论

    • After many trials, they eventually succeeded.
      • 经过许多尝试，他们终于成功了。
    • She kept working on her project and eventually finished it.
      • 她不断地在项目上努力，最终完成了它。

同义词

  • Finally

    • He finally finished his homework.
    • 他终于完成了作业。

  • Ultimately

    • Ultimately, the decision is yours.
    • 最终，决定权在你手里。

  • In the end

    • In the end, everything turned out well.
    • 最后，一切都变好了。

语法

  • 位置：通常放在句子的中间或末尾。

    • She worked hard for many years and eventually retired.
    • After several discussions, they eventually agreed on a plan.

  • 搭配：常与动词连用，表示经过一段时间或一些步骤后所达到的结果。

    • Eventually + 动词
      • Eventually realized, eventually decided, eventually became

例句解析

  1. The two countries eventually signed a peace treaty.

    • 这两个国家最终签署了和平条约。
    • “Eventually” 表示尽管可能经历了长时间的谈判和冲突，最终达成了和平。

  2. I kept looking for a job and eventually found one that I love.

    • 我不断地找工作，最终找到了一个我喜欢的。
    • “Eventually” 强调经过一段时间和努力后，达到了满意的结果。

通过这些例子和解释，希望你对 “eventually” 这个单词有了更深入的理解。

mentality

  • Chatgpt

“Mentality“ 是一个名词，指的是人的思维方式、心态、态度或心理特征。它来源于拉丁词根 “mens” 或 “mentis”，意思是“心智”或“精神”。

定义

Mentality：指一个人或一群人对待某事物的思维方式或心态。它描述了我们如何看待世界、处理问题以及应对挑战。

用法和例句

  1. 描述个体的思维方式或心态

    • She has a very positive mentality towards challenges.
      • 她对待挑战有一种非常积极的心态。

  2. 描述群体的共同心态或思维方式

    • The team’s winning mentality led them to victory.
      • 团队的取胜心态带领他们走向了胜利。

  3. 与特定领域或情况相关的心态

    • An entrepreneurial mentality is crucial for starting a business.
      • 创业心态对于创业来说是至关重要的。

  4. 可以是积极的也可以是消极的

    • A growth mentality encourages continuous learning and improvement.
      • 成长心态鼓励持续学习和改进。
    • A defeatist mentality can hinder success.
      • 失败主义心态可能会阻碍成功。

相关词汇

  • Mindset：心态、思维模式

    • They adopted a new mindset to tackle the problem.
    • 他们采用了一种新的思维模式来解决问题。

  • Attitude：态度

    • Her positive attitude makes her a great leader.
    • 她的积极态度使她成为一位出色的领导者。

  • Outlook：看法、展望

    • His optimistic outlook on life is inspiring.
    • 他对生活的乐观看法令人鼓舞。

语法

Mentality 是不可数名词，因此通常不与冠词 “a” 或 “an” 连用，也不会有复数形式。

例句解析

  1. The competitive mentality of the athletes was evident in their performance.

    • 运动员们的竞争心态在他们的表现中显而易见。
    • 这里 “mentality” 描述了运动员们为了胜利所持有的坚定和进取的态度。

  2. Changing the corporate mentality can be challenging but rewarding.

    • 改变公司的心态可能会很有挑战性，但也很有回报。
    • 这里 “mentality” 指的是公司内部对待工作、创新和合作的整体思维方式。

  3. Developing a mentality of gratitude can improve overall happiness.

    • 培养感恩的心态可以提高整体幸福感。
    • 这里 “mentality” 描述了一种思维方式或态度，即对生活中的事物心存感激。

通过这些例子和解释，希望你对 “mentality” 这个单词有了更深入的理解。

ostrich

  • Chatgpt

“Ostrich“ 是一个名词，指的是鸵鸟，这是一种大型、不飞的鸟类，主要生活在非洲。鸵鸟以其快速奔跑和独特的行为习惯而闻名。

定义

Ostrich：鸵鸟，一种不能飞的大鸟，具有长脖子、长腿和大眼睛。它们是世界上现存体型最大的鸟类。

用法和例句

  1. 描述实际的动物

    • The ostrich is the largest living bird in the world.
      • 鸵鸟是世界上现存体型最大的鸟。

  2. 比喻用法

    • To bury one’s head in the sand like an ostrich：指逃避现实或拒绝面对问题的行为。这个比喻源自一种错误的观念，即鸵鸟在受到威胁时会把头埋在沙子里，实际上鸵鸟只是低头贴近地面来观察周围的危险。
    • He’s like an ostrich with his head in the sand, refusing to acknowledge the problems in his company.
      • 他就像把头埋在沙子里的鸵鸟，拒绝承认公司里的问题。

相关词汇

  • Emu：鸸鹋，澳大利亚的一种大型不飞的鸟，类似于鸵鸟。

    • The emu, like the ostrich, is a flightless bird.
    • 鸸鹋和鸵鸟一样，是一种不能飞的鸟。

  • Flightless：不能飞的，指的是像鸵鸟这样的鸟类。

    • Penguins and ostriches are examples of flightless birds.
    • 企鹅和鸵鸟是不能飞的鸟类的例子。

语法

Ostrich 是一个可数名词。单数形式为 “ostrich”，复数形式为 “ostriches”。

例句解析

  1. Ostriches can run at speeds of up to 70 kilometers per hour.

    • 鸵鸟可以以每小时高达70公里的速度奔跑。
    • 这里 “ostriches” 是鸵鸟的复数形式，强调了鸵鸟快速奔跑的特点。

  2. The ostrich egg is the largest of any bird species.

    • 鸵鸟蛋是所有鸟类中最大的。
    • 这里 “ostrich” 修饰 “egg”，强调鸵鸟蛋的巨大体积。

  3. Stop being an ostrich and face the reality of the situation.

    • 不要再逃避现实，面对情况的现实吧。
    • 这里 “ostrich” 用作比喻，指代逃避问题的人。

文化和历史背景

鸵鸟在文化和历史上有多种象征意义。在某些文化中，鸵鸟象征着快速和力量，因为它们是跑得最快的鸟类之一。此外，由于鸵鸟大部分时间在地面上觅食，有时被错误地认为它们在受到威胁时会把头埋在沙子里，实际上它们是将头低到地面以更好地观察周围环境。

通过这些例子和解释，希望你对 “ostrich” 这个单词有了更全面的理解。

Ostrich Pillow

  • Chatgpt

“Ostrich Pillow” 是一个名词短语，指的是一种专为在旅途中或在办公室等环境中小憩而设计的枕头。这种枕头的形状和设计非常独特，模仿鸵鸟的外观，因此得名“鸵鸟枕”。

定义

Ostrich Pillow：一种创新的、舒适的枕头，设计用于提供一个私密、舒适的空间，让用户可以随时随地小憩。它的形状通常会包裹头部和手臂，提供支撑和遮光效果。

特点

  • 便携性：设计紧凑，便于携带，适合在旅途中使用。
  • 舒适性：采用柔软的材料，提供良好的支撑和舒适感。
  • 遮光效果：包裹式设计可以遮挡光线，帮助用户更容易入睡。
  • 多功能：不仅可以在旅行中使用，还适合在办公室、图书馆等地方小憩。

用法和例句

  1. 描述产品

    • I bought an Ostrich Pillow for my long flights.
      • 我买了一个鸵鸟枕，用于长途飞行。

  2. 说明用途

    • The Ostrich Pillow is perfect for napping at your desk.
      • 鸵鸟枕非常适合在办公桌上小憩。

  3. 强调舒适性和便携性

    • With the Ostrich Pillow, you can sleep comfortably anywhere.
      • 有了鸵鸟枕，你可以在任何地方舒适地睡觉。

相关词汇

  • Travel pillow：旅行枕，一般指U型枕，用于在旅行中提供颈部支撑。

    • I always take my travel pillow when I fly.
    • 我乘飞机时总是带着我的旅行枕。

  • Nap：小睡，打盹。

    • I took a nap using my Ostrich Pillow during the lunch break.
    • 我午休时用鸵鸟枕打了个盹。

  • Ergonomic：符合人体工程学的，指设计上考虑到了使用者的舒适和健康。

    • The Ostrich Pillow has an ergonomic design to support your head and neck.
    • 鸵鸟枕的设计符合人体工程学，可以支撑你的头部和颈部。

例句解析

  1. The Ostrich Pillow has a unique design that covers your head and hands for a cozy nap.

    • 鸵鸟枕有一个独特的设计，可以包裹你的头和手，让你舒适地小憩。
    • 这里强调了鸵鸟枕的独特设计和舒适性。

  2. I love using my Ostrich Pillow on long train rides to catch up on sleep.

    • 我喜欢在长途火车上使用我的鸵鸟枕来补觉。
    • 这里突出了鸵鸟枕在长途旅行中的实用性。

  3. With the Ostrich Pillow, you can create a personal napping space wherever you are.

    • 有了鸵鸟枕，你可以在任何地方创建一个个人的小憩空间。
    • 这里强调了鸵鸟枕的便携性和多功能性。

背景信息

Ostrich Pillow 是由设计公司 Studio Banana 和 Kawamura-Ganjavian 联合设计的产品。它的目的是为忙碌的现代人提供一个方便的方式，在工作或旅行时快速恢复精力。自从推出以来，Ostrich Pillow 因其创新和独特的设计受到了广泛关注。

通过这些解释和例子，希望你对 “Ostrich Pillow” 这个词组有了更全面的理解。

recruitment

  • Chatgpt

“Recruitment” 是一个名词，指的是招聘或招募人员的过程，即公司或组织寻找、吸引、面试和雇用新员工的过程。这个词源自拉丁语“recruitare”，意为“补充”。

定义

Recruitment：招聘，指公司或组织为填补职位空缺而进行的寻找、吸引和选择合适人选的过程。

用法和例句

  1. 描述招聘过程

    • The recruitment process involves several stages including application, interview, and selection.
      • 招聘过程包括多个阶段，包括申请、面试和选择。

  2. 公司或组织的招聘活动

    • Our company is focusing on recruitment to fill key positions.
      • 我们公司正在集中精力招聘，以填补关键职位。

  3. 招聘策略和方法

    • Effective recruitment strategies are essential for attracting top talent.
      • 有效的招聘策略对于吸引顶尖人才至关重要。

相关词汇

  • Hiring：雇用，指的是雇佣员工的行为。

    • The company is hiring new staff for the marketing department.
    • 公司正在为营销部门雇用新员工。

  • Job posting：职位发布，指的是在招聘网站或公告栏上发布职位空缺的信息。

    • The job posting attracted many qualified candidates.
    • 这则职位发布吸引了许多合格的候选人。

  • Interview：面试，指的是评估候选人是否适合某职位的对话或会面。

    • She prepared thoroughly for the job interview.
    • 她为这次工作面试做了充分的准备。

  • Onboarding：入职培训，指的是新员工加入公司后的培训和适应过程。

    • Effective onboarding helps new hires adjust to the company culture.
    • 有效的入职培训有助于新员工适应公司的文化。

语法

Recruitment 是不可数名词，所以它没有复数形式。它通常与冠词 “the” 连用，尤其是在谈论具体的招聘过程时。

例句解析

  1. The recruitment team is reviewing all applications this week.

    • 招聘团队本周正在审查所有申请。
    • 这里的 “recruitment team” 指负责招聘的团队。

  2. We need to improve our recruitment methods to attract more qualified candidates.

    • 我们需要改进我们的招聘方法，以吸引更多合格的候选人。
    • 这里的 “recruitment methods” 指的是招聘的方法和策略。

  3. Online recruitment has become increasingly popular in recent years.

    • 在线招聘近年来变得越来越受欢迎。
    • 这里的 “online recruitment” 指通过互联网进行的招聘活动。

背景信息

招聘是企业和组织管理中至关重要的一部分。随着技术的发展，招聘方式也在不断演变。从传统的报纸广告和招聘会，到现代的在线招聘平台和社交媒体，招聘的渠道和方法变得更加多样化和高效。

通过这些解释和例子，希望你对“recruitment”这个单词有了更全面的理解。

战略上藐视，战术上重视

  • Chatgpt

“战略上藐视，战术上重视” 的英语表达可以是：

“Strategically, show disdain; tactically, show respect.”

或者可以稍微调整一下结构，使其更流畅：

“Show disdain strategically, but show respect tactically.”

这两种表达方式都传达了在整体战略上轻视对手，但在具体战术上认真对待对手的意思。

解释

  • Strategically, show disdain 或 Show disdain strategically:

    • 这部分指在整体战略上不要把对手看得太重要，保持自信和强势。

  • Tactically, show respect 或 Show respect tactically:

    • 这部分指在具体的战术执行上，要认真对待每一个细节，不低估对手的任何行动。

例句

  • “In business, it’s important to show disdain strategically, but show respect tactically to ensure you don’t underestimate your competition.”

    • 在商业中，重要的是在战略上藐视对手，但在战术上重视对手，以确保你不会低估竞争对手。

  • “Our military strategy follows the principle of showing disdain strategically while showing respect tactically, ensuring we remain confident yet vigilant.”

    • 我们的军事战略遵循战略上藐视、战术上重视的原则，确保我们保持自信但又警惕。

希望这些表达和解释能帮助你更好地理解和使用这句话的英文版本。

contemn

  • Chatgpt

“Contemn” 是一个动词，意思是轻视、蔑视或鄙视某人或某事。它的用法相对较为正式和文学化，不如 “disdain” 或 “scorn” 那么常用。

定义

Contemn：轻视，蔑视，指对某人或某事表现出极度的不尊重或轻视。

词源

“Contemn” 源自拉丁语 “contemnere”，由 “con-”（表示完全）和 “temnere”（表示轻视）组成。

用法和例句

  1. 描述一种态度或行为

    • He was a proud man who contemned those he considered beneath him.
      • 他是一个骄傲的人，轻视那些他认为比他低的人。

  2. 在正式或文学作品中使用

    • The philosopher contemned material wealth in favor of spiritual enlightenment.
      • 这位哲学家轻视物质财富，追求精神上的启迪。

  3. 表示极度的轻视

    • She contemned the idea of lowering her standards for anyone.
      • 她鄙视为任何人降低标准的想法。

相关词汇

  • Disdain：轻视，鄙视。

    • She looked at the messy room with disdain.
    • 她轻蔑地看着乱糟糟的房间。

  • Scorn：蔑视，轻蔑。

    • He spoke with scorn about the politicians.
    • 他轻蔑地谈论那些政治家。

  • Despise：鄙视，极其不喜欢。

    • She despises liars and cheats.
    • 她鄙视说谎者和骗子。

语法

“Contemn” 是一个及物动词，因此需要一个直接宾语来表示被轻视的对象。例如：

  • To contemn someone/something：轻视某人/某事。

例句解析

  1. He contemned the very idea of compromise.

    • 他轻视妥协的想法。
    • 这里的 “contemn” 表示对妥协这一概念的极度轻视。

  2. In her arrogance, she contemned all advice from others.

    • 她傲慢地轻视他人的所有建议。
    • 这里的 “contemn” 表示她对他人建议的极度不尊重。

  3. The poet contemned the shallow values of society.

    • 诗人轻视社会的浅薄价值观。
    • 这里的 “contemn” 表示诗人对社会价值观的蔑视。

用法注意

“Contemn” 比较正式和文学化，不常用于日常口语中。更常用的同义词是 “disdain” 和 “scorn”，它们在表达轻视和蔑视时更为普遍。

通过这些解释和例子，希望你对“contemn”这个单词有了更全面的理解。

tactically

  • Chatgpt

“Tactically” 是一个副词，源自形容词 “tactical”。它表示与策略或战术相关的方式，即在操作或行动层面上如何实现目标或应对情况。

定义

Tactically：从战术上，以策略方式。指的是在具体操作层面上采取的行动和措施，通常为了实现更大的战略目标。

用法和例句

  1. 军事和战术应用

    • The soldiers moved tactically to avoid enemy detection.
      • 士兵们战术性地移动，以避免被敌人发现。

  2. 商业和管理应用

    • The company tactically reduced prices to gain a competitive edge.
      • 公司战术性地降低价格，以获得竞争优势。

  3. 运动和游戏

    • The coach adjusted the team’s formation tactically during the match.
      • 教练在比赛中战术性地调整了球队的阵型。

相关词汇

  • Strategically：从战略上，指的是总体规划或长远目标的层面。

    • The company is strategically planning to expand into new markets.
    • 公司正在从战略上规划扩展到新市场。

  • Operationally：从操作上，指的是实际操作和执行层面。

    • Operationally, the new system has improved efficiency.
    • 从操作上看，新系统提高了效率。

  • Methodically：有条理地，指的是有序和系统地进行某事。

    • She methodically reviewed all the documents before the meeting.
    • 她在会议前有条不紊地审查了所有文件。

语法

Tactically 是一个副词，用来修饰动词、形容词或其他副词，表示行动或措施是从战术或策略的角度出发的。

例句解析

  1. The team acted tactically to outmaneuver their opponents.

    • 这支队伍战术性地行动，以超越他们的对手。
    • 这里的 “tactically” 表示团队采取的行动是经过策略考虑的。

  2. By tactically placing their resources, they maximized their efficiency.

    • 通过战术性地配置资源，他们最大化了效率。
    • 这里的 “tactically” 表示资源配置是基于策略的考虑。

  3. Tactically, it was a smart move to delay the launch until the market conditions improved.

    • 从战术上看，推迟发布直到市场条件改善是一个明智的举动。
    • 这里的 “tactically” 表示推迟发布的决定是基于策略的考虑。

背景信息

“Tactically” 通常用于描述具体的、短期的行动和决策，这些行动和决策是为了支持更大的战略目标。在军事、商业、体育等领域，这个词常常用于强调在具体情境中如何采取最佳行动。

通过这些解释和例子，希望你对“tactically”这个单词有了更全面的理解。

entry.title: 【C1-Listening】Bad Smells in Code-代码里的坏味道
entry.content:
【C1-Listening】Bad Smells in Code-代码里的坏味道

Chapter 3: Bad Smells in Code
“If it stinks, change it.”

— Grandma Beck, discussing child raising philosophy By now you have a good idea of how refactoring works. But just because you know how doesn’t mean you know when. Deciding when to start refactoring (and when to stop) is just as important to refactoring as knowing how to operate the mechanics of a refactoring.

Now comes the dilemma. It is easy to explain to you how to delete an instance variable or create a hierarchy. These are simple matters. Trying to explain when you should do these things is not so cut-anddried. Rather than appealing to some vague notion of programming aesthetics (which frankly is what we consultants usually do) I wanted something a bit more solid.

I was mulling over this tricky issue when I visited Kent in Zurich. Perhaps he was under the influence of the odors of his new born daughter at the time, but he had come up with the notion describing the “when” of refactoring in terms of smells. “Smells,” you say, “and that is supposed to be better than vague aesthetics?” Well, yes. We look at lots of code, written by projects that span the gamut from wildly successful to nearly dead. And in doing so, we have learned to look for certain structures in the code that suggest (sometimes they scream for) the possibility of refactoring. (We are switching over to “we” in this chapter to reflect the fact that Kent and I wrote this chapter jointly. You can tell the difference because the funny jokes are mine and the others are his.)

One thing we won’t try to do here is give you precise criteria for when a refactoring is overdue. In our experience there is no set of metrics that rival informed human intuition. What we will do is give you indications that there is trouble that could be solved by a refactoring. You will have to develop your own sense of how many instance variables is too many instance variables and how many lines of code in a method is too many lines.

Duplicated code

Number one on the stink parade is duplicated code. If you see the same code structure in more than one place, you can be sure that your program will be better if you find a way to unify them.

The simplest duplicated code problem is when you have the same expression in two methods of the same class. Then all you have to do is Extract Method (114) and invoke the code from both places.

Another common duplication problem is when you have the same expression in two sibling subclasses. You can eliminate this duplication by using Extract Method (114) in both classes, then Pull Up Method (271). If the code is similar but not the same, then you need to use Extract Method (114) to separate the similar bits from the different bits.

You may then find you can use Form Template Method (289). If the methods do the same thing using a different algorithm, you can choose the clearer of the two algorithms and use Substitute Algorithm (132).

If you have duplicated code in two unrelated classes, consider using Extract Component (166) in one class, and then use the new component in the other. Another possibility is that the method really belongs only in one of the classes and should be invoked by the other class, or that the method belongs in a third class that should be referred to by both of the original classes. You have to decide where the method makes sense, and ensure it is there and nowhere else.

Long method

The object programs that live best and longest are those with short methods. Programmers new to objects often get the feeling that no computation ever takes place, that object programs are endless sequences of delegation. When you have lived with a program for a few years, however, you learn just how valuable all those little methods are. All of the pay-offs of indirection- explanation, sharing, and choosing- are supported by little methods.

Since the early days of programming people have realized that the longer a procedure is, the more difficult it is to understand. Older languages carried an overhead in subroutine calls, which deterred people from small method, modern OO languages have pretty much eliminated that overhead. There is still an overhead to the reader of the code as you have to switch context to look and see what the sub-procedure does. Development environments that allow you to see two methods at once help to eliminate this; but the real key to making it easy to understand small methods is good naming. If you have a good name for a method you don’t need to look at the body.

The net effect of this is that you should be much more aggressive about decomposing methods. A heuristic we follow is whenever we feel the need to comment something, we instead write a method. Such a method contains the code that was commented, but is named after what the intention of the code is, rather than how it does it. We may do this on a group of lines, or on as small as a single line of code. We will do this even if the method call is longer than the code it replaces, providing the method name explains the purpose of the code. The key here is not the method length, but the semantic distance between what the method does and how it does it.

99% of the time, all you have to shorten a method is Extract Method (114). Find a part of the method that seems to go nicely together and make a new method.

If you have a method with lots of parameters and temporary variables, they get in the way of extracting methods. If you try to use Extract Method, you end up passing so many of the parameters and temporary variables as parameters to the extracted method that the result is scarcely more readable than the original. You can often use Inline Temp (121) to get rid of the temps. Long lists of parameters can be slimmed down with Introduce Parameter Object (247) and Preserve Whole Object (241).

If you’ve tried that, and you still have too many temps and parameters,
then it’s time to get out the heavy artillery: Replace Method with Method Object (130).

How do you identify the clumps of code to extract? A good technique is to look for comments. They often signal this kind of semantic distance.

A block of code with a comment that tells you what it is doing can be replaced by a method whose name is based on the comment.

Even a single line is worth extracting if it needs explanation.

Conditionals and loops also give signs for extractions. Use Decompose Conditional (136) to deal with conditional expressions. With loops extract the loop and the code within the loop into its own method.

Large Class

When a class is trying to do too much, it often shows up as too many instance variables. When a class has too many instance variables, duplicated code cannot be far behind.

You can Extract Component (166) to bundle up a number of the variables.

Choose variables to go together in the component that makes sense with each other. For example, “depositAmount” and “deposit-Currency” are likely to belong together in a component. More generally, common prefixes or suffixes for some subset of the variables in a class suggest the opportunity for a component. If the component makes sense as a subclass you’ll find Extract Subclass (277) often is easier.

However you can only do this if the subset of instance variables that are used do not change during an object’s lifetime.

Sometimes a class will not be using all of its instance variables all of the time. If so, you may be able to Extract Component (166) or Extract Subclass (277) many times.

As with a class with too many instance variables, a class with too much code is prime breeding ground for duplicated code, chaos, and death.

The simplest solution (have we mentioned that we like simple solutions?)

is if you can eliminate redundancy in the class itself. If you have five hundred line methods with lots of code in common, you may be able to turn them into five ten line methods with another ten two line methods extracted from the original.

As with a class with a huge wad of variables, the usual solution for a class with too much code is either to Extract Component (166) or Extract Subclass (277).

Long Parameter List

In our early programming days we were taught to pass everything a routine needed in as parameters. This was understandable because the alternative was global data, and global data is evil and usually painful.

Objects change this situation because if you don’t have something you need, you can always ask another object to get it for you. Thus with objects you don’t pass in everything the method needs, instead you pass enough so that the method can get to everything it needs. A lot of what a method needs is available on method’s host class. Thus in object-oriented programs parameter lists tend to be much smaller than on traditional programs.

This is good because long parameter lists are hard to understand, they get inconsistent and difficult to use, and because you are forever changing them as you need more data. Most changes are removed by passing objects because you are much more likely to just need to make a couple of requests to get at a new piece of data.

Use Replace Parameter with Method (245) when you can get the data in one parameter by making a request of an object you already know about. This object might be a field or it might be another parameter.

Use Preserve Whole Object (241) to take a bunch of data gleaned from an object and replace it with the object itself. If you have several data items with no logical object, then Introduce Parameter Object (247).

There is one important exception to doing these changes. This is when you explicitly do not wish to create a dependency from the called object to the larger object. In those cases unpacking data and sending it along as parameters is reasonable, but pay attention to the pain involved. If the parameter list is too long or changes too often you will need to rethink your dependency structure.

Divergent Change

We structure our software to make change easier, after all software is meant to be soft. So when we make a change we want to be able to jump to a single clear point in the system and make the change.

If you look at a class and say, “Well, I will have to change these three methods every time I get a new database. I have to change these four methods every time there is a new financial instrument.” you likely have a situation where two objects are better than one. Of course you often discover this only after you’ve added a few databases or financial instruments. Any change to handle a variation should change a single class and all the typing in the new class should be expressing the variation.

So for this you identify those things you are changing and use Extract Component (166) to put them all together.

Shotgun Surgery

You whiff this when every time you add some variation, you have to make a lot of little changes to a lot of different classes. When the changes are all over the place, they are hard to find, and it’s easy to miss an important change. In this case you want to use Move Method (160) and Move Field (164) to get all the changes into a single class. If no current class looks like a good candidate, then create one. Often you can use Inline Component (170) to bring a whole bunch of behavior together. You then get a small dose of Divergent Change, but you can easily deal with that.

Feature Envy

The whole point of objects is that they are a packaging technique that packages data together with the processes upon that data. A classic smell is thus a method that seems more interested in another class than the one it’s actually in. The most common focus of the envy is the data.

We’ve lost count of the times we’ve seen a method that invokes half-adozen getting methods on another object in order to calculate some value. Fortunately the cure is obvious, the method clearly wants to be elsewhere so you use Move Method (160) to get it there. Sometimes only part of the method suffers from envy, in that case use Extract Method (114) on the jealous bit and then Move Method (160) to give it a dream home.

Of course not all cases are so cut and dried. Often a method uses features of several classes, so which one should it live with? The heuristic we use is to which class has most of the data and put the method with that data. This is often made easier by using Extract Method (114) to break into methods that go into different places.

Of course there several sophisticated patterns that break this rule.

From the [Gang of Four] Strategy and Visitor immediately leap to mind. Kent’s Self Delegation is another. You do these to combat the Divergent Change smell. The fundamental rule of thumb is to put things together that change together. Data and the behavior that references that data usually change together, but there are exceptions.

When those exceptions occur we move the behavior to keep changes in one place. Strategy and Visitor allow you to change behavior easily because it isolates the small amount of behavior that needs to be overridden, at the cost of further indirection.

Data Clumps

Data items tend to be like children — they enjoy hanging around in groups together. Often you’ll see the same three or four data items together in lots of places: fields in a couple of classes, parameters in many method signatures. Bunches of data that hang around together really ought to be made into their own object. The first step is to look for where they appear as fields. Use Extract Component (166) on the fields to turn them into an object. Then turn your attention to method signatures, using Introduce Parameter Object (247) or Preserve Whole Object (241) to slim them down. The immediate benefit here is that you can shrink a lot of parameter lists and make method calling a lot simpler.

Don’t worry about data clumps that only use some of the fields of the new object. As long as you are replacing a couple or more fields with the new object, you’ll come out ahead.

A good test is to consider deleting one of the data values: if you did this would the others make any sense? If they don’t that’s a sure sign that you have an object that’s dying to be born.

Reducing field lists and parameter lists will certainly remove a few bad smells, but once you have the objects you get the opportunity to make a nice perfume. You can now look for cases of Divergent Change which will suggest behavior that can be moved into your new classes.

Before long these classes will be productive members of society.

Case Statements

One of the most obvious symptoms of object-oriented code is its lack of case (or switch) statements. The problem with case statements is essentially that of duplication. Often you find the same case statement scattered about a program for different purposes. If you add a type to the case you have to find all these case statements and change them. The object-oriented notion of polymorphism gives you an elegant way to deal with this problem.

So most times you see a case statement you should think about polymorphism, the issue is where should the polymorphism occur. Usually case statement will switch on a type code. You will want the method on class that hosts the type code value. So use Extract Method (114) to extract the switch statement and then Move Method (160) to get it onto the class where the polymorphism is needed. At that point you have to decide whether to Replace Type Code with Subclasses (224) or Replace Type Code with State/Strategy (227). When you have set up the inheritance structure you can then Replace Switch with Polymorphism (147).

Parallel Inheritance Hierarchies

This smell is really a special case of “the same rate off change in two objects”. In this case, every time you make a subclass of one class you also have to make a subclass of another. You can recognize this smell because the prefixes of the class names in one hierarchy are the same as the prefixes in another hierarchy.

The general strategy for eliminating the duplication is to make sure that instances of one hierarchy refer to instances of the other, then use Move Method (160) and Move Field (164) the hierarchy disappears on the referring class.

Lazy Class

Each class you create costs money. If there is a class that isn’t doing enough to pay for itself, it should be eliminated.

If you have subclasses that aren’t doing enough, try to use Collapse Hierarchy (288). Nearly useless components should be subjected to Inline Component (170).

Similar subclasses

Sometimes you will see a class with four subclasses, each of which only implements three simple methods. Often you will get a vague feeling that the class doesn’t deserve subclasses, but you won’t immediately be able to see how to eliminate them. This feeling can last for months or even years. Don’t worry. If you keep nibbling away at the problems you can see how to solve, eventually you will find yourself looking at the subclasses again, and all the difficult issues to resolve will have disappeared.

Once you’ve done this, look for new opportunities to use inheritance now that you are no longer wasting it.

Temporary Field

Sometimes you will see an object where an instance variable is only set in certain circumstances. Such code is difficult to understand, because you expect an object to need all of its variables. Trying to understand why a variable is there when it doesn’t seem to be used can drive you nuts.

Use Extract Component (166) to create a home for the poor orphan variables. Put all the code that concerns the variables in the component.

You may also be able to eliminate conditional code by using Introduce Null Object (151) to create an alternative component for when the variables aren’t valid.

Middle Man

One of the prime features of objects is encapsulation: hiding internal details from the rest of the world. Often this encapsulation comes with delegation, you ask a director if she is free a meeting, she delegates the message to her diary, and gives you an answer. All well and good,there is no need to know whether the director uses a diary, an electronic gizmo, or a secretary to keep track of her appointments.

However this can go too far (particularly with those who take the Law of Demeter too seriously). You look at a class’s interface and find half the methods are delegating to this other class. After a while it’s time to cut out the middle man and talk to the object that really knows what’s going on. Use Move Method (160) and Move Field (164) to move features out of the middle man into the other objects until the middle man has nothing left.

Alternative classes with different interfaces

Use Rename Method (234) on any methods that do the same thing but have different signatures for what they do. Often this doesn’t go far enough. In these cases the classes aren’t doing enough yet. Keep using Move Method (160) to move behavior to them until the protocols are the same. If you have to redundantly move code to accomplish this, you may be able to use Extract Superclass (282) to atone.

Comments

Don’t worry, we aren’t saying that people shouldn’t write comments.

In our olfactory analogy, comments aren’t a bad smell, indeed they are a sweet smell.

The reason we mention them here is because comments are often used as a deodorant. It’s surprising how often you look at thickly commented code, and notice that the comments are there because the code is bad.

Thus comments lead us to bad code that has all the rotten whiffs we’ve discussed in the rest of this chapter. Our first action to remove the bad smells by refactoring. When we’re done we often find that the comments are now superfluous.

When you feel the need to write a comment, try first to refactor the code so that any comment would be superfluous.

Chapter 3: Bad Smells in Code 第 3 章：代码中的坏味道

“If it stinks, change it.”
“如果臭了，就换掉。”

— Grandma Beck, discussing child raising philosophy
——贝克奶奶，讨论育儿哲学

By now you have a good idea of how refactoring works. But just because you know how doesn’t mean you know when. Deciding when to start refactoring (and when to stop) is just as important to refactoring as knowing how to operate the mechanics of a refactoring.
现在你已经很清楚重构是如何运作的了。但仅仅因为你知道如何做并不意味着你知道什么时候做。对于重构来说，决定何时开始重构（以及何时停止）与了解如何操作重构机制同样重要。

Now comes the dilemma. It is easy to explain to you how to delete an instance variable or create a hierarchy. These are simple matters. Trying to explain when you should do these things is not so cut-and-dried. Rather than appealing to some vague notion of programming aesthetics (which frankly is what we consultants usually do) I wanted something a bit more solid.
现在困境来了。向您解释如何删除实例变量或创建层次结构很容易。这些都是简单的事情。尝试解释何时应该做这些事情并不是那么简单。我不想诉诸一些模糊的编程美学概念（坦率地说，这是我们顾问通常所做的），我想要一些更扎实的东西。

I was mulling over this tricky issue when I visited Kent in Zurich. Perhaps he was under the influence of the odors of his new born daughter at the time, but he had come up with the notion describing the “when” of refactoring in terms of smells. “Smells,” you say, “and that is supposed to be better than vague aesthetics?” Well, yes. We look at lots of code, written by projects that span the gamut from wildly successful to nearly dead. And in doing so, we have learned to look for certain structures in the code that suggest (sometimes they scream for) the possibility of refactoring. (We are switching over to “we” in this chapter to reflect the fact that Kent and I wrote this chapter jointly. You can tell the difference because the funny jokes are mine and the others are his.)
当我访问苏黎世的肯特郡时，我正在思考这个棘手的问题。也许他当时受到了刚出生的女儿的气味的影响，但他提出了用气味来描述重构“何时”的概念。 “闻起来，”你说，“这应该比模糊的美学更好吧？”嗯，是。我们查看了大量由项目编写的代码，这些项目的范围从非常成功到几乎死亡。在这样做的过程中，我们学会了在代码中寻找某些表明（有时他们尖叫着）重构可能性的结构。 （我们在本章中改用“我们”，以反映肯特和我共同撰写这一章的事实。你可以看出区别，因为有趣的笑话是我的，其他的是他的。）

One thing we won’t try to do here is give you precise criteria for when a refactoring is overdue. In our experience there is no set of metrics that rival informed human intuition. What we will do is give you indications that there is trouble that could be solved by a refactoring. You will have to develop your own sense of how many instance variables is too many instance variables and how many lines of code in a method is too many lines.
我们在这里不会尝试做的一件事是为您提供重构何时过期的精确标准。根据我们的经验，没有任何衡量标准可以与人类直觉相媲美。我们要做的就是向您表明存在可以通过重构解决的问题。您必须自行判断有多少实例变量算实例变量太多，以及方法中的多少行代码算不算太多行。

Duplicated code重复的代码

Number one on the stink parade is duplicated code. If you see the same code structure in more than one place, you can be sure that your program will be better if you find a way to unify them.
臭游行中排名第一的是重复代码。如果您在多个地方看到相同的代码结构，那么如果您找到一种方法来统一它们，您可以确信您的程序会更好。

The simplest duplicated code problem is when you have the same expression in two methods of the same class. Then all you have to do is Extract Method (114) and invoke the code from both places.
最简单的重复代码问题是当同一类的两个方法中有相同的表达式时。然后您所要做的就是提取方法 (114) 并从两个地方调用代码。

Another common duplication problem is when you have the same expression in two sibling subclasses. You can eliminate this duplication by using Extract Method (114) in both classes, then Pull Up Method (271). If the code is similar but not the same, then you need to use Extract Method (114) to separate the similar bits from the different bits.
另一个常见的重复问题是当两个兄弟子类中有相同的表达式时。您可以通过在两个类中使用 Extract Method (114)，然后使用 Pull Up Method (271) 来消除这种重复。如果代码相似但不相同，则需要使用提取方法（114）将相似位与不同位分开。

You may then find you can use Form Template Method (289). If the methods do the same thing using a different algorithm, you can choose the clearer of the two algorithms and use Substitute Algorithm (132).
然后您可能会发现可以使用表单模板方法（289）。如果这些方法使用不同的算法执行相同的操作，您可以选择两种算法中更清晰的一个并使用替代算法 (132)。

If you have duplicated code in two unrelated classes, consider using Extract Component (166) in one class, and then use the new component in the other. Another possibility is that the method really belongs only in one of the classes and should be invoked by the other class, or that the method belongs in a third class that should be referred to by both of the original classes. You have to decide where the method makes sense, and ensure it is there and nowhere else.
如果两个不相关的类中有重复的代码，请考虑在一个类中使用提取组件 (166)，然后在另一个类中使用新组件。另一种可能性是，该方法实际上只属于其中一个类，并且应该由另一个类调用，或者该方法属于第三个类，而该第三个类应该由两个原始类引用。您必须决定该方法在哪里有意义，并确保它在那里而不是在其他地方。

Long method长方法

The object programs that live best and longest are those with short methods. Programmers new to objects often get the feeling that no computation ever takes place, that object programs are endless sequences of delegation. When you have lived with a program for a few years, however, you learn just how valuable all those little methods are. All of the pay-offs of indirection- explanation, sharing, and choosing- are supported by little methods.
寿命最长、寿命最长的目标程序是那些方法较短的程序。刚接触对象的程序员经常会感觉没有发生任何计算，对象程序是无休止的委托序列。然而，当您使用一个程序几年后，您就会知道所有这些小方法有多么有价值。间接的所有回报——解释、共享和选择——都是通过一些小方法来支持的。

Since the early days of programming people have realized that the longer a procedure is, the more difficult it is to understand. Older languages carried an overhead in subroutine calls, which deterred people from small method, modern OO languages have pretty much eliminated that overhead. There is still an overhead to the reader of the code as you have to switch context to look and see what the sub-procedure does. Development environments that allow you to see two methods at once help to eliminate this; but the real key to making it easy to understand small methods is good naming. If you have a good name for a method you don’t need to look at the body.
自从编程的早期以来，人们就意识到程序越长，理解起来就越困难。较旧的语言在子例程调用方面会产生开销，这阻止了人们使用小方法，现代面向对象语言几乎消除了这种开销。对于代码的读者来说仍然有一定的开销，因为您必须切换上下文才能查看子过程的作用。允许您同时查看两种方法的开发环境有助于消除这种情况；但让小方法易于理解的真正关键是良好的命名。如果你有一个好的方法名称，你就不需要查看方法体。

The net effect of this is that you should be much more aggressive about decomposing methods. A heuristic we follow is whenever we feel the need to comment something, we instead write a method. Such a method contains the code that was commented, but is named after what the intention of the code is, rather than how it does it. We may do this on a group of lines, or on as small as a single line of code. We will do this even if the method call is longer than the code it replaces, providing the method name explains the purpose of the code. The key here is not the method length, but the semantic distance between what the method does and how it does it.
这样做的最终效果是您应该更加积极地使用分解方法。我们遵循的一个启发是，每当我们觉得需要注释某些内容时，我们就会编写一个方法。此类方法包含已注释的代码，但以代码的意图命名，而不是根据其执行方式命名。我们可以在一组行上执行此操作，或者在小至单行代码上执行此操作。即使方法调用比它所替换的代码长，我们也会这样做，只要方法名称解释了代码的用途。这里的关键不是方法的长度，而是方法做什么和如何做之间的语义距离。

99% of the time, all you have to shorten a method is Extract Method (114). Find a part of the method that seems to go nicely together and make a new method.
99% 的情况下，您所需要缩短的方法就是 Extract Method (114)。找到该方法中似乎可以很好地结合在一起的部分并创建一个新方法。

If you have a method with lots of parameters and temporary variables, they get in the way of extracting methods. If you try to use Extract Method, you end up passing so many of the parameters and temporary variables as parameters to the extracted method that the result is scarcely more readable than the original. You can often use Inline Temp (121) to get rid of the temps. Long lists of parameters can be slimmed down with Introduce Parameter Object (247) and Preserve Whole Object (241).
如果您的方法包含大量参数和临时变量，它们会妨碍提取方法。如果您尝试使用提取方法，您最终会传递如此多的参数和临时变量作为提取方法的参数，以致结果几乎不比原始结果更具可读性。您通常可以使用 Inline Temp (121) 来消除临时值。可以使用“引入参数对象”(247) 和“保留整个对象”(241) 来精简长参数列表。

If you’ve tried that, and you still have too many temps and parameters,
如果您已经尝试过，但仍然有太多的临时值和参数，

then it’s time to get out the heavy artillery: Replace Method with Method Object (130).
那么是时候拿出重炮了：用方法对象替换方法（130）。

How do you identify the clumps of code to extract? A good technique is to look for comments. They often signal this kind of semantic distance.
如何识别要提取的代码块？一个好的技巧是寻找注释。它们经常表示这种语义距离。

A block of code with a comment that tells you what it is doing can be replaced by a method whose name is based on the comment.
带有注释的代码块可以告诉您它正在做什么，可以用名称基于注释的方法来替换。

Even a single line is worth extracting if it needs explanation.
如果需要解释，即使是一行也值得提取。

Conditionals and loops also give signs for extractions. Use Decompose Conditional (136) to deal with conditional expressions. With loops extract the loop and the code within the loop into its own method.
条件和循环也给出了提取的标志。使用 Decompose Conditional (136) 来处理条件表达式。使用循环将循环和循环内的代码提取到其自己的方法中。

Large Class大类

When a class is trying to do too much, it often shows up as too many instance variables. When a class has too many instance variables, duplicated code cannot be far behind.
当一个类试图做太多事情时，它通常会表现为实例变量太多。当一个类的实例变量过多时，重复的代码也就不远了。

You can Extract Component (166) to bundle up a number of the variables.
您可以提取组件 (166) 来捆绑多个变量。

Choose variables to go together in the component that makes sense with each other. For example, “depositAmount” and “deposit-Currency” are likely to belong together in a component. More generally, common prefixes or suffixes for some subset of the variables in a class suggest the opportunity for a component. If the component makes sense as a subclass you’ll find Extract Subclass (277) often is easier.
选择在组件中组合在一起的彼此有意义的变量。例如，“depositAmount”和“deposit-Currency”可能一起属于一个组件。更一般地说，类中某些变量子集的公共前缀或后缀暗示了组件的机会。如果该组件作为子类有意义，您会发现提取子类 (277) 通常更容易。

However you can only do this if the subset of instance variables that are used do not change during an object’s lifetime.
但是，只有当所使用的实例变量子集在对象的生命周期内不发生更改时，您才能执行此操作。

Sometimes a class will not be using all of its instance variables all of the time. If so, you may be able to Extract Component (166) or Extract Subclass (277) many times.
有时，类不会一直使用其所有实例变量。如果是这样，您可以多次提取组件 (166) 或提取子类 (277)。

As with a class with too many instance variables, a class with too much code is prime breeding ground for duplicated code, chaos, and death.
与具有过多实例变量的类一样，具有过多代码的类是重复代码、混乱和死亡的主要滋生地。

The simplest solution (have we mentioned that we like simple solutions?)
最简单的解决方案（我们是否提到过我们喜欢简单的解决方案？）

is if you can eliminate redundancy in the class itself. If you have five hundred line methods with lots of code in common, you may be able to turn them into five ten line methods with another ten two line methods extracted from the original.
就是你是否可以消除类本身的冗余。如果您有 500 行方法并且有很多共同代码，您可以将它们变成 5 个十行方法，并从原始代码中提取另外 10 个两行方法。

As with a class with a huge wad of variables, the usual solution for a class with too much code is either to Extract Component (166) or Extract Subclass (277).
与具有大量变量的类一样，对于具有过多代码的类，通常的解决方案是提取组件 (166) 或提取子类 (277)。

Long Parameter List长参数列表

In our early programming days we were taught to pass everything a routine needed in as parameters. This was understandable because the alternative was global data, and global data is evil and usually painful.
在我们早期的编程时代，我们被教导将例程所需的所有内容作为参数传递。这是可以理解的，因为替代方案是全球数据，而全球数据是邪恶的，而且通常是痛苦的。

Objects change this situation because if you don’t have something you need, you can always ask another object to get it for you. Thus with objects you don’t pass in everything the method needs, instead you pass enough so that the method can get to everything it needs. A lot of what a method needs is available on method’s host class. Thus in object-oriented programs parameter lists tend to be much smaller than on traditional programs.
对象改变了这种情况，因为如果你没有需要的东西，你总是可以要求另一个对象为你获取它。因此，对于对象，您不必传递方法所需的所有内容，而是传递足够的内容，以便方法可以获取它需要的所有内容。方法所需的很多内容都可以在方法的宿主类上找到。因此，在面向对象的程序中，参数列表往往比传统程序小得多。

This is good because long parameter lists are hard to understand, they get inconsistent and difficult to use, and because you are forever changing them as you need more data. Most changes are removed by passing objects because you are much more likely to just need to make a couple of requests to get at a new piece of data.
这很好，因为长参数列表很难理解，它们变得不一致且难以使用，并且因为您需要更多数据时会永远更改它们。大多数更改都是通过传递对象来删除的，因为您更有可能只需要发出几个请求即可获取新数据。

Use Replace Parameter with Method (245) when you can get the data in one parameter by making a request of an object you already know about. This object might be a field or it might be another parameter.
当您可以通过向您已知的对象发出请求来获取一个参数中的数据时，请使用“用方法替换参数”(245)。该对象可能是一个字段，也可能是另一个参数。

Use Preserve Whole Object (241) to take a bunch of data gleaned from an object and replace it with the object itself. If you have several data items with no logical object, then Introduce Parameter Object (247).
使用“保留整个对象”(241) 获取从对象收集的一堆数据，并将其替换为对象本身。如果您有多个没有逻辑对象的数据项，则引入参数对象 (247)。

There is one important exception to doing these changes. This is when you explicitly do not wish to create a dependency from the called object to the larger object. In those cases unpacking data and sending it along as parameters is reasonable, but pay attention to the pain involved. If the parameter list is too long or changes too often you will need to rethink your dependency structure.
进行这些更改有一个重要的例外。这是当您明确不希望创建从被调用对象到更大对象的依赖关系时。在这些情况下，解包数据并将其作为参数发送是合理的，但要注意所涉及的痛苦。如果参数列表太长或更改太频繁，您将需要重新考虑您的依赖结构。

Divergent Change发散性变化

We structure our software to make change easier, after all software is meant to be soft. So when we make a change we want to be able to jump to a single clear point in the system and make the change.
毕竟软件本来就应该是软的，我们构建软件是为了让改变变得更容易。因此，当我们进行更改时，我们希望能够跳转到系统中的单个明确点并进行更改。

If you look at a class and say, “Well, I will have to change these three methods every time I get a new database. I have to change these four methods every time there is a new financial instrument.” you likely have a situation where two objects are better than one. Of course you often discover this only after you’ve added a few databases or financial instruments. Any change to handle a variation should change a single class and all the typing in the new class should be expressing the variation.
如果您查看一个类并说：“好吧，每次获得新数据库时我都必须更改这三个方法。每次有新的金融工具出现时，我都必须改变这四种方法。”您可能会遇到两个对象比一个对象更好的情况。当然，您通常只有在添加了一些数据库或金融工具后才会发现这一点。处理变体的任何更改都应该更改单个类，并且新类中的所有类型都应该表达变体。

So for this you identify those things you are changing and use Extract Component (166) to put them all together.
因此，为此，您需要确定要更改的内容，并使用提取组件 (166) 将它们全部放在一起。

Shotgun Surgery霰弹枪手术

You whiff this when every time you add some variation, you have to make a lot of little changes to a lot of different classes. When the changes are all over the place, they are hard to find, and it’s easy to miss an important change. In this case you want to use Move Method (160) and Move Field (164) to get all the changes into a single class. If no current class looks like a good candidate, then create one. Often you can use Inline Component (170) to bring a whole bunch of behavior together. You then get a small dose of Divergent Change, but you can easily deal with that.
当每次添加一些变化时，您都必须对许多不同的类进行大量的小更改，您就会感到这一点。当变化遍布各处时，就很难发现，而且很容易错过重要的变化。在本例中，您希望使用 Move Method (160) 和 Move Field (164) 将所有更改放入单个类中。如果当前没有一个类看起来像一个好的候选者，那么创建一个。通常，您可以使用内联组件 (170) 将一大堆行为整合在一起。然后你会得到少量的发散变化，但你可以轻松应对。

Feature Envy功能羡慕

The whole point of objects is that they are a packaging technique that packages data together with the processes upon that data. A classic smell is thus a method that seems more interested in another class than the one it’s actually in. The most common focus of the envy is the data.
对象的全部要点在于它们是一种打包技术，将数据以及对该数据的处理打包在一起。因此，经典气味是一种似乎对另一个类比它实际所在的类更感兴趣的方法。最常见的嫉妒焦点是数据。

We’ve lost count of the times we’ve seen a method that invokes half-adozen getting methods on another object in order to calculate some value. Fortunately the cure is obvious, the method clearly wants to be elsewhere so you use Move Method (160) to get it there. Sometimes only part of the method suffers from envy, in that case use Extract Method (114) on the jealous bit and then Move Method (160) to give it a dream home.
我们已经记不清有多少次看到一个方法调用另一个对象上的六种获取方法来计算某个值。幸运的是，解决方法是显而易见的，该方法显然想要在其他地方，因此您可以使用“移动方法”(160) 将其到达那里。有时，只有部分方法受到嫉妒，在这种情况下，对嫉妒位使用提取方法 (114)，然后使用移动方法 (160) 给它一个梦想的家。

Of course not all cases are so cut and dried. Often a method uses features of several classes, so which one should it live with? The heuristic we use is to which class has most of the data and put the method with that data. This is often made easier by using Extract Method (114) to break into methods that go into different places.
当然，并不是所有的情况都是如此。通常一个方法会使用多个类的特性，那么它应该使用哪一个呢？我们使用的启发式方法是哪个类拥有最多的数据，并将该方法与该数据放在一起。通过使用 Extract Method (114) 来分解进入不同位置的方法，这通常会变得更容易。

Of course there several sophisticated patterns that break this rule.
当然，有几种复杂的模式打破了这一规则。

From the [Gang of Four] Strategy and Visitor immediately leap to mind. Kent’s Self Delegation is another. You do these to combat the Divergent Change smell. The fundamental rule of thumb is to put things together that change together. Data and the behavior that references that data usually change together, but there are exceptions.
脑海中立即浮现出《四人帮》的策略和访客。肯特的自我委托是另一个例子。你这样做是为了对抗发散变化的味道。基本的经验法则是将变化的事物放在一起。数据和引用该数据的行为通常会一起更改，但也有例外。

When those exceptions occur we move the behavior to keep changes in one place. Strategy and Visitor allow you to change behavior easily because it isolates the small amount of behavior that needs to be overridden, at the cost of further indirection.
当这些异常发生时，我们会移动行为以将更改保留在一处。策略和访问者允许您轻松更改行为，因为它隔离了需要覆盖的少量行为，但代价是进一步间接。

Data Clumps数据块

Data items tend to be like children — they enjoy hanging around in groups together. Often you’ll see the same three or four data items together in lots of places: fields in a couple of classes, parameters in many method signatures. Bunches of data that hang around together really ought to be made into their own object. The first step is to look for where they appear as fields. Use Extract Component (166) on the fields to turn them into an object. Then turn your attention to method signatures, using Introduce Parameter Object (247) or Preserve Whole Object (241) to slim them down. The immediate benefit here is that you can shrink a lot of parameter lists and make method calling a lot simpler.
数据项往往就像孩子一样——他们喜欢成群结队地在一起。通常，您会在很多地方看到相同的三到四个数据项：几个类中的字段、许多方法签名中的参数。一堆聚集在一起的数据确实应该被制作成它们自己的对象。第一步是查找它们作为字段出现的位置。对字段使用提取组件 (166) 将其转换为对象。然后将注意力转向方法签名，使用引入参数对象 (247) 或保留整个对象 (241) 来精简它们。这里直接的好处是你可以缩小很多参数列表并使方法调用变得更加简单。

Don’t worry about data clumps that only use some of the fields of the new object. As long as you are replacing a couple or more fields with the new object, you’ll come out ahead.
不必担心仅使用新对象的某些字段的数据块。只要您用新对象替换几个或多个字段，您就会取得领先。

A good test is to consider deleting one of the data values: if you did this would the others make any sense? If they don’t that’s a sure sign that you have an object that’s dying to be born.
一个好的测试是考虑删除一个数据值：如果您这样做，其他数据值是否有意义？如果他们不这样做，那就是一个明确的信号，表明你有一个即将诞生的物体。

Reducing field lists and parameter lists will certainly remove a few bad smells, but once you have the objects you get the opportunity to make a nice perfume. You can now look for cases of Divergent Change which will suggest behavior that can be moved into your new classes.
减少字段列表和参数列表肯定会消除一些难闻的气味，但是一旦你拥有了这些对象，你就有机会制作出美味的香水。您现在可以寻找发散性变化的案例，这些案例将建议可以转移到您的新类别中的行为。

Before long these classes will be productive members of society.
不久之后，这些阶级将成为社会的富有生产力的成员。

Case Statements条件分支语句

One of the most obvious symptoms of object-oriented code is its lack of case (or switch) statements. The problem with case statements is essentially that of duplication. Often you find the same case statement scattered about a program for different purposes. If you add a type to the case you have to find all these case statements and change them. The object-oriented notion of polymorphism gives you an elegant way to deal with this problem.
面向对象代码最明显的症状之一是缺少 case（或 switch）语句。 case 语句的问题本质上是重复。通常，您会发现出于不同目的，相同的 case 语句分散在程序中。如果向 case 添加类型，则必须找到所有这些 case 语句并更改它们。面向对象的多态性概念为您提供了一种处理此问题的优雅方法。

So most times you see a case statement you should think about polymorphism, the issue is where should the polymorphism occur. Usually case statement will switch on a type code. You will want the method on class that hosts the type code value. So use Extract Method (114) to extract the switch statement and then Move Method (160) to get it onto the class where the polymorphism is needed. At that point you have to decide whether to Replace Type Code with Subclasses (224) or Replace Type Code with State/Strategy (227). When you have set up the inheritance structure you can then Replace Switch with Polymorphism (147).
所以大多数时候你看到一个case语句你应该考虑多态性，问题是多态性应该发生在哪里。通常 case 语句会打开类型代码。您将需要托管类型代码值的类上的方法。因此，使用 Extract Method (114) 提取 switch 语句，然后使用 Move Method (160) 将其放到需要多态性的类中。此时，您必须决定是用子类替换类型代码 (224) 还是用状态/策略替换类型代码 (227)。设置继承结构后，您可以用多态性替换 Switch (147)。

Parallel Inheritance Hierarchies并行继承层次结构

This smell is really a special case of “the same rate off change in two objects”. In this case, every time you make a subclass of one class you also have to make a subclass of another. You can recognize this smell because the prefixes of the class names in one hierarchy are the same as the prefixes in another hierarchy.
这种气味实际上是“两个物体变化率相同”的特例。在这种情况下，每次创建一个类的子类时，您还必须创建另一个类的子类。您可以识别出这种气味，因为一个层次结构中的类名前缀与另一个层次结构中的前缀相同。

The general strategy for eliminating the duplication is to make sure that instances of one hierarchy refer to instances of the other, then use Move Method (160) and Move Field (164) the hierarchy disappears on the referring class.
消除重复的一般策略是确保一个层次结构的实例引用另一层次结构的实例，然后使用移动方法 (160) 和移动字段 (164)，层次结构在引用类上消失。

Lazy Class懒惰类

Each class you create costs money. If there is a class that isn’t doing enough to pay for itself, it should be eliminated.
您创建的每个类都需要花钱。如果有一个阶级的努力不足以维持其自身的收入，那么它就应该被淘汰。

If you have subclasses that aren’t doing enough, try to use Collapse Hierarchy (288). Nearly useless components should be subjected to Inline Component (170).
如果您的子类做得不够，请尝试使用 Collapse Hierarchy (288)。几乎无用的组件应该受到内联组件（170）的影响。

Similar subclasses类似的子类
Sometimes you will see a class with four subclasses, each of which only implements three simple methods. Often you will get a vague feeling that the class doesn’t deserve subclasses, but you won’t immediately be able to see how to eliminate them. This feeling can last for months or even years. Don’t worry. If you keep nibbling away at the problems you can see how to solve, eventually you will find yourself looking at the subclasses again, and all the difficult issues to resolve will have disappeared.
有时你会看到一个类有四个子类，每个子类只实现三个简单的方法。通常你会隐约感觉到该类不值得有子类，但你不会立即知道如何消除它们。这种感觉可以持续数月甚至数年。不用担心。如果你不断地啃那些你能看到如何解决的问题，最终你会发现自己再次查看子类，所有需要解决的难题都将消失。

Once you’ve done this, look for new opportunities to use inheritance now that you are no longer wasting it.
完成此操作后，请寻找新的机会来使用继承，因为您不再浪费它了。

Temporary Field临时字段

Sometimes you will see an object where an instance variable is only set in certain circumstances. Such code is difficult to understand, because you expect an object to need all of its variables. Trying to understand why a variable is there when it doesn’t seem to be used can drive you nuts.
有时您会看到一个对象，其中的实例变量仅在某些情况下设置。这样的代码很难理解，因为您期望一个对象需要它的所有变量。试图理解一个似乎没有被使用的变量为什么会存在，这会让你发疯。

Use Extract Component (166) to create a home for the poor orphan variables. Put all the code that concerns the variables in the component.
使用提取组件 (166) 为可怜的孤儿变量创建一个家。将所有涉及变量的代码放在组件中。

You may also be able to eliminate conditional code by using Introduce Null Object (151) to create an alternative component for when the variables aren’t valid.
您还可以通过使用引入空对象 (151) 来消除条件代码，以便在变量无效时创建替代组件。

Middle Man中间人

One of the prime features of objects is encapsulation: hiding internal details from the rest of the world. Often this encapsulation comes with delegation, you ask a director if she is free a meeting, she delegates the message to her diary, and gives you an answer. All well and good,there is no need to know whether the director uses a diary, an electronic gizmo, or a secretary to keep track of her appointments.
对象的主要特征之一是封装：向外界隐藏内部细节。通常这种封装伴随着授权，你问一位主管她是否有空开会，她将信息委托给她的日记，然后给你一个答案。一切都很好，没有必要知道主任是否使用日记、电子小玩意或秘书来记录她的约会。

However this can go too far (particularly with those who take the Law of Demeter too seriously). You look at a class’s interface and find half the methods are delegating to this other class. After a while it’s time to cut out the middle man and talk to the object that really knows what’s going on. Use Move Method (160) and Move Field (164) to move features out of the middle man into the other objects until the middle man has nothing left.
然而，这可能太过分了（特别是对于那些过于认真对待德墨忒尔定律的人）。您查看一个类的接口，发现一半的方法委托给了另一个类。过了一会儿，就可以去掉中间人，与真正知道发生了什么的对象进行对话。使用移动方法 (160) 和移动字段 (164) 将特征从中间人移到其他对象中，直到中间人没有任何剩余。

Alternative classes with different interfaces具有不同接口的替代类

Use Rename Method (234) on any methods that do the same thing but have different signatures for what they do. Often this doesn’t go far enough. In these cases the classes aren’t doing enough yet. Keep using Move Method (160) to move behavior to them until the protocols are the same. If you have to redundantly move code to accomplish this, you may be able to use Extract Superclass (282) to atone.
对执行相同操作但具有不同功能签名的任何方法使用重命名方法 (234)。通常这还不够。在这些情况下，班级做得还不够。继续使用移动方法 (160) 将行为移动到它们，直到协议相同。如果您必须冗余地移动代码来完成此操作，您可以使用 Extract Superclass (282) 来弥补。

Comments注释

Don’t worry, we aren’t saying that people shouldn’t write comments.
别担心，我们并不是说人们不应该写注释。

In our olfactory analogy, comments aren’t a bad smell, indeed they are a sweet smell.
在我们的嗅觉比喻中，注释并不是难闻的气味，实际上它们是一种甜蜜的气味。

The reason we mention them here is because comments are often used as a deodorant. It’s surprising how often you look at thickly commented code, and notice that the comments are there because the code is bad.
我们在这里提到它们的原因是因为注释经常被用作除臭剂。令人惊讶的是，当您查看大量注释的代码时，您会发现注释的存在是因为代码很糟糕。

Thus comments lead us to bad code that has all the rotten whiffs we’ve discussed in the rest of this chapter. Our first action to remove the bad smells by refactoring. When we’re done we often find that the comments are now superfluous.
因此，注释会导致我们编写出糟糕的代码，其中包含我们在本章其余部分讨论的所有腐烂的味道。我们的第一个行动是通过重构来消除不良气味。当我们完成后，我们经常发现注释现在是多余的。

When you feel the need to write a comment, try first to refactor the code so that any comment would be superfluous.
当您觉得需要编写注释时，请首先尝试重构代码，以便任何注释都是多余的。

tags.tag: Listening - C1-Listening - English

entry.title: 多邻国优美句子
entry.content:
01

我们不需要办又大又豪华的婚礼。

We don’t need to have a big and fancy wedding.

02

没有人唱歌比你唱得更糟糕！

Nobody sings worse than you do!

03

How strange were those animal costumes?

那些动物服装有多奇怪？

04

那个音乐家去年在音乐节上。

That musician was at the music festival last year.

05

Today’s performance was better than yesterday’s.

今天的表演比昨天的更好。

06

How difficult was it to design that costume?

设计那套服装有多难？

07

She took pictures with the cast backstage.

她在后台跟全体演员拍了照片。

08

如果下雨，我们就不能烤这些蔬菜了！

If it rains, we won’t be able to grill these vegetables!

09

Are we going to the neighbors’ housewarming party?

我们要去邻居的暖房聚会吗？

10

This is the tennis racket which I bought for class.

这是我为体育课买的网球拍。

11

When’s the back to school sale?

开学特卖是什么时候？

12

Our boss gave each salesperson a different job.

我们的老板给了每个销售员不同的任务。

13

他想要什么类型的漫画书？

What sorts of comic book does he want?

14

The round glasses which you like are on sale!

喜欢的圆形眼镜在特价出售！

15

We’ll certainly buy a present for Anna.

我们肯定会给安娜买一个礼物。

16

Turn left after the library.

过图书馆后左转。

17

发动机出了问题吗？

Is there a problem with the engine?

18

Have you ever been to the Grand Canyon?

你去过大峡谷吗？

19

政府在试着帮助人们。

The government is trying to help people.

20

What kind of gas do we need?

我们需要哪种汽油？

21

She took pictures with the cast backstage.

她在后台跟全体演员拍了照片。

22

Oh no, I don’t have a driver’s license.

噢不，我没有驾照。

23

Don’t worry, the officers will find the bomb.

别担心，警官们会找到炸弹。

24

Is that news headline about the government?

那个新闻头条是关于政府吗？

第 6 阶段，第 7 部分 描述家居用品

01

Why shouldn’t she change her major?

她为什么不应该换她的专业？

02

Couldn’t he take biology in the evening?

他不可以在晚上修生物吗？

03

他对明天的会议感到很紧张。

He’s nervous about tomorrow’s meeting

04

Couldn’t you take computer science?

你不可以修计算机科学吗？

05

我记得我跟那个男的见面的日子。

I remember the day when I met that guy.

06

她打算主修中文吗？

Is she going to major in Chinese?

07

艾玛昨天跟我聊天了。

Emma chatted with me yesterday.

08

There’s a good chance I’ll get hired!

我很有可能会被录用！

09

Cycling on the Brooklyn Bridge is fun.

在布鲁克林大桥上骑自行车很好玩！

10

My advisor offered me good advice.

我的导师给我提供了很好的建议。

11

Which position did you apply for.

你申请了哪个职位？

12

在第二十一街上有一个杂货店吗？

Is there a grocery store on Twenty First Street?

13

My advisor offered me good advice.

我的导师给我提供了很好的建议。

14

华尔街靠近布鲁克林大桥吗？

Is Wall Street close to the Brooklyn Bridge?

15

我们这个周末可以看一场足球比赛。

We can watch a soccer match this weekend.

16

I’m picking up my luggage now.

我现在在取我的行李。

17

Does your roommate study English at NYU?

你的室友在纽约大学学习英语吗？

18

How many people are they going to hire?

他们打算雇用多少人？

19

You can find various shops on Fifth Avenue.

你可以在第五大道上找到各种各样的商店。

20

Don’t forget to pick up your luggage.
不要忘了取你的行李。

21

我很确定明天天气会很好。
I’m sure the weather will be nice tomorrow.

22

It’s the last apartment on the left.
它是左边的最后一个公寓。

23

Sometimes there are concerts in Central Park.
有的时候在中央公园里有音乐会。

24

I’m sure you’ll have a successful career.
我很确定你会有很成功的事业。

25

There’s a nice cafe across from the library.
在图书馆对面有一个不错的咖啡厅。

26

It’s the last apartment on the left.
它是左边的最后一个公寓。

27

Do we live near Twenty-Second Street?
我们住在第二十二街附近吗？

28

She applied for a position in this company.
她申请了这家公司的一个职位。

在课堂上与人交流

01

I’m sure you’ll find hot pot in Chinatown.
我很确定你在中国城会找到火锅。

02

The store is on FirstStreet.
商店在第一街上。

03

I’m sure you’ll find hot pot in Chinatown.
我很确定你在中国城会找到火锅。

04

The store is on FirstStreet.
商店在第一街上。

32

Let’s look around the museum.
咱们在博物馆四处看看吧。

31

The store is on FirstStreet.
商店在第一街上。

30

I’m sure you’ll find hot pot in Chinatown.
我很确定你在中国城会找到火锅。

31

The store is on FirstStreet.
商店在第一街上。

32

我们肯定会给我们的孩子们买一些礼物！
We’ll certainly buy some presents for our kids!

33

艾玛喜欢什么类型的香水？
What sorts of perfume does Emma like?

34

你更喜欢短发还是长发？
Do you prefer short hair or long hair?

35

Let’s buy some school supplies!
咱们买一些学习用品吧！

36

The store is on FirstStreet.
商店在第一街上。

37

不要忘了看清单的最下面！
Don’t forget to look at the bottom of the list!

38

这是一台单面的打印机。
This is a single-sided printer.

39

汤姆为了艺术课买了这些蜡笔。
Tom bought these crayons for art class.

40

Here’s the perfume which my daughter likes best.
这是我的女儿最喜欢的香水。

在课堂上与人交流

01

We should get gas, shouldn’t we?
我们应该加油，不是吗？

02

I believe that we should take this exit.
我觉得我们就应该走这个出口。

03

Duo told us that he wants to drive.
多儿告诉我们他想要开车。

04

There’s a good chance she’ll win the election!
她很有可能会赢得选举！

05

Why do news anchors always wear suits?
新闻主播们为什么总是穿西装？

06

The store is on FirstStreet.
商店在第一街上。

07

你能在服务区给我们买一些甜食吗？
Can you get us some sweets at the rest stop?

08

Have you ever been to the Grand Canyont.
你去过大峡谷吗？

09

服务区在出口的标志再过去一点。
The rest stop is past the sign for the exit.

10

We’ll talk to the officer who saved everyone!
我们会跟救了大家的警官聊聊！

11

突发新闻，市政厅着火了！
Breaking news, city hall is on fire!

12

We’re glad that we protected everyone today.
我们很高兴今天我们保护了大家。

13

The store is on FirstStreet.
商店在第一街上。

14

我们为什么不走高速公路？
Why don’t we take the highway?

15

They don’t sell lemonade at the gas station.
在加油站他们不卖柠檬水。

16

Shouldn’t we take calculus before we graduate?
我们在我们毕业之前不应该修微积分吗？

17

当一个新生压力很大！
It’s stressful to be a freshman!

18

她可以在网上修心理学，不是吗？
She could take psychology online, couldn’t she?

19

Most restaurants on this street have great food!

这句话中有两个部分需要完成，其中涉及到动词形式的一致性和时态：

句子分析：

  1. 第一句：

    • “You said you ____ going to sleep until I woke you up.”
    • 这里的关键在于主句的谓语动词是 said，表示过去的动作，因此从句中的时态需要与过去时间一致。
    • 空格处应填 were，因为在过去时间里，表示一种计划或意图的状态（过去进行时）。
    • 完整句子：**”You said you were going to sleep until I woke you up.”**

  2. 第二句：

    • “You said, ‘We ____ going to sleep until you wake us up.’”
    • 引号内的内容是直接引语，直接引用当时说的话，因此可以保留当时的时态。
    • 由于是正在计划的动作，在引语中需要使用 are（现在进行时）。
    • 完整句子：**”You said, ‘We are going to sleep until you wake us up.’”**

总结：

  • 在间接引语中，将时态退回到过去，所以第一个空格用 were。
  • 在直接引语中，保持原话不变，所以第二个空格用 are。

最终答案：

  • “You said you were going to sleep until I woke you up.”
  • “You said, ‘We are going to sleep until you wake us up.’”

Day-916

You must’ve watched that video a hundred times!那个视频你肯定看了一百遍了！
I did. I remember every single scene.是的。我记得每一个场景。
I didn’t. It was a difficult test anyway.我没有。不管怎样，这是一个困难的测试。

Anna is writing about the most influential singers of the 20th century and their effect on music today.
安娜正在写20世纪最有影响力的歌手及其对当今音乐的影响。
embassyearacheerrand大使馆耳痛差事

It must have been so cool to be there in person!亲自去那里一定很酷！

Listening to music from the sixties and seventies has inspired Lin to write her own songs. 听六七十年代的音乐激发了林书豪创作自己歌曲的灵感。
bitelungswingswaste咬肺翅膀废物

It must have been so exciting to be at those concerts!参加那些音乐会一定很刺激吧！

In my eyes, the most hopeful music came out of the sixties.在我眼里，最有希望的音乐来自六十年代。
I saw you. You were wearing a long dress.我看见你了。你穿着长裙。
I agree. It was all about peace and love back then.我同意。那时候一切都与和平与爱有关。

In my eyes she truly changed American music.在我看来，她确实改变了美国音乐。

Popular music was mainly about love, but it all changed with Bob Dylan.流行音乐主要是关于爱情的，但随着鲍勃·迪伦的出现，一切都变了。
That’s right. He was the same as all the rest.没错。他和其他人一样。
That’s right. He wrote protest songs, didn’t he?没错。他写了抗议歌曲，不是吗？

It all seemed so simple.这一切似乎都很简单。

I learned about the influential role of jazz in American music culture.我了解到爵士乐在美国音乐文化中的重要作用。
That’s true. It changed many other music styles.没错。它改变了许多其他的音乐风格。
She got involved in fighting for the environment.她参与了环境保护的斗争。

It all began when John met Paul.这一切都始于约翰遇见保罗。

She must have been happy to be loved by so many people.被这么多人爱着，她一定很开心。

The new music style became popular fast. It all happened in a year!新的音乐风格迅速流行起来。这一切都发生在一年内！
It’s amazing how well she plays chess!她下棋下得真厉害！
It’s amazing how quickly the trends change!趋势变化之快令人惊讶！

That rock band inspired many teenagers to start playing guitar.那个摇滚乐队激励了许多青少年开始弹吉他。
I agree. It made me want to speak to the manager.我同意。这让我想和经理谈谈。
Well, I guess they had a positive influence!我猜他们对我有积极的影响。

Jimi Hendrix was the most influential guitar player of all time!吉米·亨德里克斯是有史以来最有影响力的吉他手！
Right! He changed the way guitarists play forever.没错。他永远改变了吉他手的演奏方式。
Right! Everybody copied his style of painting.对！每个人都模仿他的画风。

Day-917

How did those bands influence you, dad?那些乐队对你有什么影响，爸爸？

They were an amazing band, and had performed in every city in the US.他们是一支了不起的乐队，在美国的每个城市都演出过。

He had worldwide success.他在全世界都取得了成功。

They’d first released an album in 1980. They were famous for their powerful voices and long hair.
他们在1980年首次发行了一张专辑。他们以强有力的声音和长发而闻名。

Music videos helped singers get worldwide attention.音乐视频帮助歌手获得了全世界的关注。

He had never written a song before, but he was a great singer.他以前从未写过歌，但他是一个伟大的歌手。

That album sold over 10 million copies worldwide.那张专辑在全世界卖了1000万张。

Alternative rock bands had really become popular.另类摇滚乐队真的很受欢迎。

Thousands of hippies attended a huge concert in 1969.数千名嬉皮士参加了1969年的一场大型音乐会。

That rock band inspired many teenagers to start playing guitar.那个摇滚乐队激励了许多青少年开始弹吉他。

That band influenced many alternative rock bands who came after them.
那个乐队影响了许多后来的另类摇滚乐队。

920-Day

你量过客厅了吗？

让我看看我能不能给你一些提示。让我看看我能不能给你一些提示。

a

END

tags.tag: English

entry.title: 百词斩
entry.content:
2024-11-25

01 accustom

v.使习惯于

词根助记
ac去+custom习惯→试着去习惯→accustom使习惯于

He has accustomed himself to using chopsticks.
他已经习惯了使用筷子。

02 commercial

adj.商业的；商用的；贸易的；商业化的；以获利为目的的；【财】商业的，盈利的；n.商业广告

词根助记
com共同+ merc交易+ial….的→共同交易的→commercial商业的

This city has been a major center of commercial activity for a long time.
长期以来，这个城市都是一个主要的商业活动中心。

Taking advantage of this rich bounty, Alaska’s commercial fisheries have developed into some of the largest in the world.
利用这一丰富的资源，阿拉斯加的商业渔业已经发展成为世界上最大的渔业之一。
来源：剑7 Test4 阅读

… one finds general aviation aircraft (few of which can climb above 5,490m anyway), and commercial turboprop aircraft.z
-种是通用航空飞机(无论如何，很少有飞机能爬升到5490米以上)和商用涡轮螺旋桨飞机。
来源：剑8 Test1 阅读

03 deviation

n.偏差；偏离，背离

词根助记
deviat(e)偏离+ ion名词后缀→ deviation偏差

The course of the blue paper plane shows a deviation.
蓝色纸飞机的航线显示出偏差。

Large deviations could happen, and they could result in one end of the tunnel not being usable.
可能会发生较大的偏差，并可能导致隧道的一端无法使用。
来源：剑16 Test4 阅读

04 feat

n.绝技，功绩，武艺

词根助记
feat=fact做大事→n.绝技，本领；功绩，功劳

Fire spitting is an amazing feat!
喷火真是一门神奇的技艺！

Their radar achieves feats of detection and navigation that would strike an engineer dumb with admiration.
他们的雷达实现了探测和导航的功绩，这将使一个工程师赞叹不已。他们的雷达实现了探测和导航的壮举，这会让工程师钦佩得哑口无言。
来源：剑7 Test1 阅读

05 mold

v. 塑造；使形成；把…塑造成；n.霉菌；模子；气质

象形助记

I mold the clay with my hands to make a cup.
我用手把黏土塑造成一个杯子。

06 rehearse

v.排练，预演

象形助记

We are rehearsing the final scene of the drama show.
我们在排练这个话剧表演的最后一幕场景。

07 imply

vt.意味着；暗示；暗指；表明

词根助记
im进入+ply重叠，折叠→重叠表达→imply意味着

The traffic increase implies more air pollution.
交通量增加意味着空气污染越来越严重。

This definition implies that iconoclasts are different from other people ..
这个定义意味着打破传统的人与其他人不同..
来源：剑9 Test2 阅读

08 clumsy

adj. 笨拙的，不灵活的；拙劣的，不得体的

象形助记

Why is there a clumsy elephant in the restaurant?
为什么餐厅里有一头笨拙的大象？

09 cultivate

v.耕作，种植，栽培；培养，发展

词根助记
cult耕种，培养+ivate表动词→cultivate耕作；培养

Despite the burning sun, these boys were cultivating with joy.
尽管烈日炎炎，这些少年还是在快乐地耕作着。

Coconuts are cultivated in different ways in America and the Pacific.
在美洲和太平洋地区，椰子有不同的种植方式。
来源：剑13 Test3 阅读

10 spouse

n.配偶，夫妇；夫，妻；v.和..结婚

谐音助记
spouse谐音：死抱死
死抱着自己的”配偶”，死也要在一起。

The young spouses planned to travel abroad.
这对年轻夫妇计划去国外旅行。

… adults can often identify their children or spouses by scent.
成年人通常也能通过气味识别出自己的孩子或配偶。
来源：剑8 Test2 阅读

2024-11-26

01 exclusive

adj. 独有的；奢华的；排外的；n. 独家新闻

词根助记
ex向外+ clus关,闭+ ive 形容词词尾→都排除在外→exclusive独有的

These are the exclusive seats for our VIP.
这些是我们贵宾的专属座位。

Throughout this period, the Arabs were the exclusive importers of spices to Europe.
在这一时期，阿拉伯人是欧洲香料的独有进口商。
来源：剑15 Test1 阅读

02 hoe

n.锄头；v. 用锄耕地

联想助记
小心不要让“锄头”（hoe）砸到你的脚趾（toe）。

I used the hoe to prepare the soil for planting.
我用锄头疏松土壤，准备种植。

03 attraction

n.景点；吸引，魅力；有吸引力的事物；游览胜地；引力，万有引力

象形助记

The Great Wall is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Beijing.
长城是北京最受欢迎的旅游景点之一。

Describe a tourist attraction you enjoyed visiting.
描述一个你喜欢游览的景点。
来源：剑16 Test1 口语

D Hardy’s aim was to show the attraction of isolation.
哈迪的目的是展示孤独的吸引力。
来源：剑15 Test1 阅读

04 emission

n.排放物；发射；放射物；散发物；排放；【化】发射，放射；【物】放射

词根助记
emiss放出+ion名词后缀→emission排放物

The emissions from the coal power station will pollute the air.
燃煤发电站排放的废气会污染空气。

The energy use and carbon emissions this generates is spectacular and largely unnecessary.
由此产生的能源消耗和碳排放物是惊人的，而且在很大程度上是不必要的。
来源：剑14 Test2 阅读

05 proposition

n.提议；计划；命题；事业，生意；【财】提议；vt.向….求欢

词根助记
propos打算，建议+ition名词后缀→proposition提议

He made the proposition to his co-workers to go out for food after work.
他向他的同事提议下班后一起出去吃饭。

… to spur managers to think more expansively about how trends could engender new value propositions in their core markets,
为了促使管理者更广泛地思考趋势如何在其核心市场中产生新的价值主张。
来源：剑13 Test2 阅读

06 frustration

n.沮丧，不满；挫败；【财】受挫；【法】合同无法执行，合同目的无法实现

词根助记
frustrat=frustrate挫败+ion名词后缀→frustration挫败

The boy falls in great frustration because of his poor learning ability.
男孩因自己学习能力差而深感沮丧。

Many bears have been seen to hit out at ice and snow-seemingly out of frustration.
许多熊被看到过撞向冰雪，似乎是出于沮丧。
来源：剑16 Test1 阅读

07 enact

v.颁布；制定法律；扮演

词根助记
en使….进入状态+ act行动→进入行动→ enact颁布

Congress enacted a law which would protect certain types of wild animals.
国会通过了一部保护特定类型野生动物的法律。

08 vest

n.汗衫，背心，马甲；v.给….穿衣服；授予；归属

象形助记

I put on my white vest to get ready for exercise.
我穿上我的白色背心准备锻炼。

… fitting 26 children with audio-recording vests that captured language and sound
给26个小孩穿上有录音功能的背心，以收集他们的语言文字和声音·.
来源：剑13 Test3 阅读

09 torture

vt.折磨；对…施以酷刑，拷问；n.酷刑，折磨；adj.遭受重创的；饱受煎熬的

词根助记
tort扭转+ure表名词→扭曲别人→torture折磨

My friend tortured us with her terrible singing.
我朋友用她糟糕的歌声折磨我们。

10 stroll

v.散步；溜达，游荡；n.漫步；漫步，散步；闲荡，溜达；溜达；vt..游.；在….步在….漫步

I stroll with my dog every morning.
我每天早上和我的狗一起散步。

No wonder that people who stroll around exhibitions are filled with nostalgia,..
难怪漫步展览的人们充满了怀旧之情；
来源：剑9 Test4 阅读

2024-11-27

01 teem

vi. 充满；大量存在于；v.生下

象形助记

The Great Wall is always teeming with tourists.
长城上总是挤满了游客。

He examined a drop of water from a nearby lake and found it teeming with tiny creatures
他检查了附近湖中的一滴水，发现里面充满了微小的生物。
来源：剑16 Test2 阅读

02 attributable

adj.可归因于….的

词根助记
atribut(e)….归因于 + .a.le能..的→attributable可归因于….的

The squirrels being homeless is attributable to the reduction of forest.
小松鼠之所以无家可归，是因为森林面积的减少。

… accounts for 84 % of the CO2 emissions attributable to transport.
因为交通运输而产生的二氧化碳排放量占了84%
来源：剑10 Test1 阅读

03 soy

n.大豆；酱油

象形助记

Soy can be made into tofu.
大豆可以用来制作豆腐。

04 overcast

adj.阴天的；阴暗的；愁闷的；v.使沮丧；遮蔽；n.．【气象学】阴，阴天；遮盖物（尤指云、雾等）；郁闷，忧愁，沮丧；[采矿】风桥

象形助记

The sky is gray and overcast.
天空阴沉灰暗。

05 mitigate

v.减轻，缓和；【财】减少

She takes the pill to mitigate the dizziness.
她吃药以减轻头晕的症状。

On the question of mitigating the risks farmers face, most essayists called for greater state intervention.
在减轻农民面临风险的问题上，大多数评论家呼吁加大国家干预力度。
来源：剑12 Test6 阅读

06 vivid

adj 生动的，清晰的（记忆、描述)；，（颜色）鲜艳的，强烈的（颜色、光）；丰富的；逼真的

词根助记
viv生命+id形容词后缀→有生命的→vivid生动的，清晰的 (记忆、描述)

This painting is a vivid representation of two horses.
这幅画是对两匹马的生动再现。

Bingham writes about the approach in vivid style in his book.
宾厄姆在他的书中生动地描述了这种方法。
来源：剑12 Test6 阅读

It has also been proposed that trees may produce vivid red colours …
也有人提出，树木可能会产生鲜艳的红色…
来源：剑10 Test3 阅读

07 pint

n.品脱（容量单位，在美国约合0.473升）；【数】品脱(pt.)

象形助记

This big cup can hold a pint of beer.
这个大杯子可以装下一品脱啤酒。

08 impose

v.把…强加给；强制实行，强迫接受

联想助记
im (音同：硬)+ pose放，硬放就是”把…强加给”（impose)

My mother always imposes pressure on me.
我妈妈总是给我施加压力。

.., and that this ought to be imposed on the whole of the speech community.
.···.这应该强加给整个言论界。
来源：剑9 Test3 阅读

09 scorch

v.烧焦；枯萎；vi.高速行驶，疾驰，飞驰

谐音助记
scorch谐音：杀过去，引申为战争→战争使一切都化为焦土→ scorch烧焦

The leaves have been scorched by the sun’s heat.
树叶被太阳晒焦了。

… after some of the largest fires in state history scorched thousands of acres…
在该州历史上最大的几场大火烧毁了数千英亩土地之后.
来源：剑10 Test4 阅读

10 huddle

v.聚集在一起，挤作一团；把身子蜷成一团，蜷缩；使聚集在一起；n.挤在一起的人，一堆杂乱的东西

联想助记
当想要cuddle（抱抱）的时候我们就huddle（”聚集在一起”)

Baby penguins huddle together while their parents are not around.
当父母不在身边时，小企鹅们会挤作一团。

2024-11-28

01 portray

v.描绘；描述；扮演

联想助记
把颜料倒（pour）在托盘（tray）上”描绘”（portray）图画。

I like to portray beautiful flowers in my paintings.
我喜欢画美丽的花。

… if the film portrays a character playing the piano, the sounds of the piano are projected.
.如果电影描绘了一个弹钢琴的角色，钢琴的声音就会被放出来。
来源：剑11 Test4 阅读

02 onset

n(尤指某种坏事情的）开始；攻击，袭击；(疾病)发作

联想助记
打开（on）设置（set），就是一个”开始”（onset）。

The sudden onset of winter wreaked havoc on transport.
冬天的突然降临让交通系统陷入了混乱。

With the onset of statehood, however, the State of Alaska took over management of its own fisheries ..
然而，随着州地位的确立，阿拉斯加州在州宪法的指导下接管了自己的渔业管理…
来源：剑7Test4 阅读

03 countenance

n.面容，表情，气色；v.支持，赞成

象形助记

Her countenance is showing a great deal of anger.
她的表情显示出极度的愤怒。

04 filling

n.馅；adj 能填饱肚子的

词根助记
fll（使）装满；填补+动名词后缀ing→filling（补牙）填料；馅

I love the filling in the dumplings.
我喜欢吃饺子里的馅儿。

05 dawn

n.开始；黎明；开端；萌芽；v.开始；破晓；开始清楚

谐音助记
dawn谐音：咚咚的一声“黎明”到来，是一天的“开始”。

The steam revolution marked a new dawn in the human history.
蒸汽革命为人类历史揭开了新的篇章。

The economic importance of forests has been understood since the dawn of man.
自从人类出现以来，人们就已经认识到森林的经济重要性。
来源：剑7 Test3 阅读

06 file

v.提起（诉讼），提出（申请）；把….归档；锉；列队行进；提交；n.文件；文件夹；档案，卷宗；锉刀；纵列，单列；公文箱；【计】文件

联想助记
fill和file有点像，fill the file是填写”文件”（file）。

Filing for divorce is not a happy option for couples.
离婚诉讼对夫言并不是一个愉快的选项。

But financially I didn’t really benefit from it, because I never filed for a patent.
但在经济上我并没有真正从中受益，因为我从未提出申请专利。
来源：剑14 Test1 阅读

07 scum

n. 浮沫，浮渣

象形助记

As the scum rises, skim it off.
当浮沫浮起时，请将它撇去。

08 transformation

n.变化，改造，转变；；转型；【化〗转化；【数】变换

词根助记
trans变+ form形状+ ation名词后缀→transformation变化

She went through a significant transformation in the last four years.
她在过去的四年里经历了巨大的变化。

. by means of photosynthesis, forests produce oxygen through the transformation of solar energy …
….森林通过光合作用转化太阳能来产生氧气..
来源：剑7 Test3 阅读

09 pragmatic

adj. 实际的，注重实效的；国事的，团体事务的；n.爱管闲事的人；专断的人；国事诏书；实际家

词根助记
prag做事+形容词后缀ic→pragmatic务实的；实用主义的

I don’t need any fancy designs, I prefer my furniture to be more pragmatic.
我不需要花哨昂贵的设计，我更喜欢实用的家具。

10 pursuit

n.追求，寻找；追赶，跟踪；事业；消遣；追踪

词根助记
pursu=pursue追求+it名词后缀，表抽象名词→pursuit追求

He is in pursuit of being a rich man.
他正追求着成为一个有钱人。

…thinkers throughout the ages may have struggled to reconcile the pursuit of happiness with other human values.,…
一直以来，思想家们可能一直在努力协调对幸福的追求与人类其他价值观之间的关系.
来源：剑13 Test4 阅读

The thylacine was not a fast runner and probably caught its prey by exhausting it during a long pursuit.
